awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Legal and Moral Sources of Trust in the Social Lives of Displaced People
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported by this award investigates the local-level legal and moral relationships through which displaced people are incorporated into new social environments. Massive global population displacement has produced what some label the greatest humanitarian crisis since the founding of the United Nations. But explaining the full ramifications of displacement remains a challenging problem for social scientists. Those who ascribe to rational choice models may see the decision to move as a reasoned choice given situational factors. Others point to structural factors, such as political and economic inequalities, to explain dislocation. But these explanations do not account for the legal and ethical relationships, grounded in trust, that make it possible for displaced people to be re-emplaced after relocation. This research will investigate the micro-processes through which trust is cultivated by and for displaced people. Understanding these processes, critical to comprehending what is needed to end the crisis,  is important for advancing social science theory about displacement and for U. S. policy.

The research will be carried out by Stanford University anthropology doctoral student, Kerem Can Ussakli, as part of advanced training in how to conduct empirically grounded scientific fieldwork, under the supervision of Dr. Thomas Blom Hansen. The research will be conducted in the Kurdistan Regional Government of Iraq. This is an appropriate site because after gaining autonomy, the region has become known for its resilience, social cohesion, and hospitality for the internally displaced populations. The researcher will look at sponsorship relations between Iraqi internally displaced people and their Kurdish hosts, to examine how individuals create cultural networks and moral mechanisms of trust even in conditions of prolonged violence. He will work with local non-governmental organizations (NGOs), humanitarian workers, lawyers, displaced people, and local residents to document the varying legal statuses and claims raised by each actor. Data will be collected through a mixed-methods approach including participant observation, interviews and life-histories and archival research. Findings from this research will be useful to policymakers who seek better-informed policies in the fields of state-building, refugee settlement, government, and international law.

por.por_cntn:
Situated in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KRI), this project looks at the interplay between everyday sociality and security between and among internally-displaced persons and their hosts to investigate the micro-operations of sovereignty. Since 1970s, Kurdish national movement in Iraq has gained concessions towards what is today an autonomous government recognized under the Iraqi constitution. The emergence of sub-sovereign institutions, forces and aspirations in Iraq such as the KRI are discussed in two ways: i) Such sub-sovereignties evidence the artificiality of Iraq’s social fabric, leading to a society characterized by exploitation, opportunism and senseless violence, or; ii) people have prior, ethno-sectarian affiliations to the nation-state, leading to endogenous violence between acquaintances and neighbors, and identities defined exclusively through political factions.

 

Based on 20-months of ethnographic fieldwork, this research argues that both of these frames omit historically rehearsed practices of trust-building that create socially acceptable forms of survival. To understand these practices, the researcher has conducted participant observation and surveys in social gatherings, feasts, private homes, government and non-governmental buildings, labor markets, neighborhood corner shops and checkpoints located within the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. These locations were identified as places where different face-to-face interaction between and amongst internally-displaced Iraqi Arabs and their Iraqi Kurdish hosts took place. The researcher has also conducted interviews, in order to gather information about procedures and to collect life-histories of displaced persons.

 

The research takes as its subject over 2 million people who have been internally displaced to the Kurdistan Regional Government from other parts of Iraq since 2003. Through an analysis of displacement trajectories and stories, this research shows how displaced people are caught in webs of security mechanisms that were put in place following the dismantling of the Ba’athist regime, changes in the procedural applications and symbolic constructions of Iraqi nationality, and the Global War on Terror. Caught between these webs, displaced persons often lived in the KRI under the sponsorship of local Kurds. They justified these sponsorships through social bonds and ractices of sociality that expressed proximity and intimacy. These relations were seen as forms of investment: they ensured financial recuperation, and a guarantee for survival in case they are not able to return to their places of origin.

 

The research has shown that for Iraqi Kurds, sponsorship offers were justified in reference to longstanding friendships, humanitarian sentiment, religious faith, vocabularies and practices of hospitality. Following its constitutional recognition as an autonomous region in 2005, the Kurdistan Region of Iraq remained safe and prospered economically through neoliberal expansionism that indexed being an “Iraqi Kurd” as a privileged class. In the absence of a legally codified definition of Kurdish citizenship in the autonomous region, security requirements that sealed off the KRI from civil conflict also helped to make distinctions between nationalities and create unstable hierarchies between them. Series of financial, political, and humanitarian crises between 2014 – 2017 cast serious doubt to the validity of this privilege. In this context, the ability of offering sponsorship was seen as a performative enactment of Kurdish citizenship brought to relief the importance of political allegiances and hierarchical dynamics. Kurds who offered sponsorships lived in border towns were those who branded themselves as sociable big men, who used their social skills and reputation to sway the security officers. Coming from disputed territories between the Kurdistan Regional Government and the Iraqi Federal Government, they competed for political influence over Kurdish families who were dispossessed and displaced as part of the Arabization campaigns (1978 – 1991). They could only offer sponsorships if they were affiliated with parties who held political control over security forces, and did so in order to increase culturally valued prestige and social capital.

 

As another instance of prolonged disputes around territorial, financial and political sovereignty, debates around sponsorship privileged the Kurdish citizen’s vouching over official information coming from the Iraqi Federal Government. Government officials of the Kurdistan Regional Government defended these sponsorship requirements as necessary due to distrust towards paperwork and documentation coming from the Iraqi Federal Government. The research has shown that these disputes have also led to the significant prolongation of displacement, and have introduced many social and legal complexities to the issue of returns.

 

Despite prolonged absence and dispute between governmental and political forces that reflect fragmented sovereignties, ordinary citizens in conflict zones rely on everyday patterns of social interaction and sociability to construct alternative sovereign futures. Today international organizations such as United Nations High Commission for Refugees and International Crisis Group, as well as the nation-state donors to these funds highlight social cohesion as key to the resolution of conditions that led to and prolong displacement. This research shows that the roots of social cohesion lie in historically rehearsed practices of sociality and trust-building that make strangers legible to each other under situations of conflict.
